awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Reducing Student Resistance to Active Learning: Applying Research Results to Faculty Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project involved investigators at the University of Michigan (Award DUE-1821488), Bucknell University (Award DUE-1821036), the University of Texas at Austin (Award DUE-1821092), and the University of Oregon (Award DUE-1821277). Replacing lectures with "active learning" in college and university STEM classrooms is a proven means of increasing students' understanding of concepts and their persistence in STEM studies. Yet it remains a challenge to spread active learning approaches widely because both faculty members and students tend to resist change in their habits of teaching and learning. This project focuses on student resistance as a barrier to the adoption of evidence-based teaching practices such as active learning. Student resistance is one of the most actionable and least studied barriers to STEM instructional change. The investigators' prior research, which focused primarily on engineering education, identified strategies that instructors can use to reduce student resistance to active learning. In this project, they will design and test a workshop to educate instructors in different STEM disciplines about using strategies to reduce student resistance.  They will conduct research studies to examine how student resistance influences instructors' plans to use active learning in future classes, and to test whether their previous findings apply to other institutions and student populations.

Through this effort, at least 90 STEM instructors, representing a broad set of two-year and four-year institutions with diverse student populations, will be equipped to use evidence-based strategies to reduce student resistance to active learning.  The changes in their attitudes and practices will be studied to understand the effect of this professional development on student resistance and on the sustained adoption of active learning. The investigators' primary research questions are: (1) To what degree does the carefully designed faculty development workshop promote the use of explanation and facilitation strategies to reduce resistance? (2) To what extent does instructor motivation (i.e., self-efficacy and value) for adopting active learning moderate the effect of the workshop on instructors' behavior? To what extent do other course-level and institution-level variables moderate the effect of the workshop on instructors' behavior? (3) What is the effect of instructors' use of strategies to reduce student resistance on student affective response and on student resistance to active learning? To what extent does student resistance vary with the individual instructor's experience using active learning? (4) Does student affective response mediate the effect of instructor use of strategies on resistance? (5) To what extent does student resistance to active learning influence instructors' plans to continue using active learning in future course offerings?  The investigators intend to disseminate the materials and results from this project via publications in scientific and science education journals, and presentations at science education and professional development conferences that reach a large number of STEM faculty members.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of the study, we developed, piloted, and tested the effectiveness of an online professional development workshop designed to support instructors' use of active learning by increasing their use of strategies to reduce student resistance. We provided this professional development to over 200 university STEM instructors across the US. To understand the impact of this workshop, we developed, piloted, and tested several new survey scales, including instruments to examine instructor motivation and use of active learning and strategies to reduce student resistance, instructor perception of barriers to implementing active learning, and instructor perception of student affective and behavioral resistance. We also developed, piloted, and tested a student survey and an observation instrument to triangulate instructor and student reports of active learning use and student resistance to active learning. Using a randomized control trial, we found that our workshop impacted instructors' strategies to reduce student resistance to active learning. This impact was more pronounced for instructors who perceived student resistance as a significant barrier to using active learning in the classroom. Additionally, we found that instructors and students disagreed on the degree to which students resisted active learning and that students’ affective and behavioral response was predicted by their sense of belonging and self-efficacy. These findings have been published in international peer-reviewed journals, published in conference proceedings, and presented at national and international conferences.

Intellectual Merit

Findings from our research studies inform STEM faculty development research and implementation. We demonstrated that faculty perception of student resistance informs faculty’s self-efficacy, thus reducing the likelihood of using active learning.  Our research represents one of the few examinations of the impact of faculty’s perception of students’ response to instruction outside of university-administered teaching evaluations.  In particular, we found that STEM instructors’ beliefs about students’ responses to active learning influenced their self-efficacy for active learning pedagogies. However, in two separate studies, we found that faculties’ perceptions of resistance to active learning did not accurately represent students’ resistance to active learning.  These findings suggest that faculty development professionals and researchers should consider establishing tools to help faculty more accurately assess their students’ resistance to active learning. 

Our rigorous randomized control tested the efficacy of a short workshop on faculty use of strategies to reduce student resistance. We found that the short 4-hour workshop did increase the faculty’s use of planning, explanation, and facilitation strategies.  However, we did not find that student-reported resistance decreased due to faculty’s participation in the workshop.

Broader Impacts

Our surveys have already been used by other researchers wishing to investigate faculty adoption of active learning, and we expect even more studies to use the instruments in the future. Team members include the findings from the study in their faculty professional development seminars, including five National Effective Teaching Institute events, as well as other national and university-specific trainings. Our findings about the efficacy of our faculty development activities will inform more effective workshops to result in greater adoption of active learning. In turn, this will improve student learning, promote greater student success, and increase diversity in engineering
